Clocker: an open source macOS menubar app to plan and organize through timezones

Backstory of collabrating with the creator of open source macOS app rebuild it from groundup.

Posted Nov 22, 2018

So it all started with an email to the Abhishek Banthia (creator and developer of Clocker) praising the app and asking if he has any plans to improve the design and experience of the app. Luckily he had some plans for a design overhaul and some cool new features.

So I started off with the goal of
• Rebuild the visual language of the app
• Add couple of new features in
• Learn as much as possible on macOS app design patterns

Clocker screenshot on both light mode and dark mode

Calendar at a glance

New calendar feature

One of the most requested feature was the ability to see calendar at a glance. This is a big addition and it’ll have ripple effects on other parts of the app, so we took careful consideration on how to implement the feature and its interactions. Our goal here was to keep it simple while providing the necessary information.

With this addition, Clocker will become the all in one tool to plan and organize your schedule through multiple timezones.

Preferences panel

Exisiting preferences panel was not using the system default pattern, which resulted in inconsitent experience across other apps users use every day. We restructured the information architecture of the preferences and designed it from scratch to match the system default pattern.

App icon

New Clocker app icon

The all new design needed a new good looking app icon to match. After couple of iterations, following is the final version of new app icon that we decided on.

We found few ways to illustrate the well known features as well new upcoming features on app icon. More than one “seconds” needle indicate the multi time zone feature and mini dots on background layer inidicate the upcoming calendar feature. This was a way for us to give a little bit of meaning and liviness to the app icon.

As a designer who never worked on any macOS apps, this was a way for me to learn and execute macOS app design and interaction. The lack of community resources for macOS app design and interactions compared to iPhone and iPad is really surprising, so I decided to open source the designs as a way for me to give back to the community.

The all new design and features are not implemented yet but I suggest downloading the current version of Clocker on App Store. This will be a life saver when you work with remote teams on multiple timezones.
